content: SECTION 1. UNIFORM TREATMENT OF ABSENTEE BALLOTS FOR UNIFORMED AND OVERSEAS VOTERS. Section 102 of the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act is amended to accept and count valid absentee ballots from overseas voters for federal elections, regardless of postmark, if there is evidence of mailing before the election date. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act is amended to accept and count valid absentee ballots from overseas voters for federal elections, with conclusive evidence of mailing before the election date. The Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act is amended to include requirements set by the Presidential designee and enforce penalties for knowingly providing false information regarding the mailing date of an absentee ballot for overseas voters. SEC. 2. Use of military installations and reserve component facilities as polling places. The amendment allows military installations to be used as polling places for Federal, State, or local elections. The Secretary of a military department can make a building on a military installation available for this purpose, and once designated, it must continue to be used as a polling place. The Secretary can make military installations available as polling places for elections, with advance notice required if the site will no longer be used for this purpose. The Secretary can designate military installations as polling places for elections, with advance notice needed if the facility will no longer be used for voting purposes. State facilities can also be used as polling places for any election, despite certain legal restrictions. The amendment allows military installations and reserve component facilities to be used as polling places in elections, in accordance with specific sections of title 10 of the United States Code. The amendment permits military installations and reserve component facilities to serve as polling places for elections, following certain sections of title 10 of the United States Code. Additionally, for the 2002 Federal Elections, sites used in 2000 must be available for polling in November 2002. The amendment allows military installations and reserve component facilities to be used as polling places for the 2002 Federal Elections in November. Amendments are made to section 2670 of title 10, United States Code, regarding the use of buildings on military installations by the American National Red Cross and as polling places in elections. The amendment allows military installations to be used as polling places for Federal, State, and local elections.
